  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Intermediate Japanese</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>JAPN 0300 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15232]</span></h3>


  	Further practice of patterns and structures of the language. Readings are introduced on aspects of Japanese culture and society to develop reading and writing skills, enhance vocabulary, and provide points of departure for conversation in Japanese. Prerequisite: JAPN 0200 or equivalent. The East Asian Studies department wishes to provide language instruction to all interested students. If you are unable to register for this course due to enrollment limits but are dedicated to learning Japanese, please contact the instructor via email.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hiroshi+Tajima">Hiroshi Tajima</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=111 Thayer St-Watson Institute">111 Thayer St-Watson Institute</a> 112</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=111 Thayer St-Watson Institute">111 Thayer St-Watson Institute</a> 112</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Japanese I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>JAPN 0500 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15233]</span></h3>


  	Continued practice in reading, writing, and speaking. Emphasizes the development of reading proficiency and speaking in cultural contexts. Students read actual articles and selections from Japanese newspapers. Course includes translation, with writing and discussion in Japanese. Films and video tapes are shown as supplementary materials. Prerequisite: JAPN 0400 or equivalent.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Yuko+I+Jackson">Yuko I Jackson</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=111 Thayer St-Watson Institute">111 Thayer St-Watson Institute</a> 112</div>
						<div class="times">10:00 - 10:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=111 Thayer St-Watson Institute">111 Thayer St-Watson Institute</a> 116</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>14</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Japanese II</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>JAPN 0700 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15234]</span></h3>


  	Reading of articles from Japan's press with discussion in Japanese. Focuses on explanations and drills on the fine points in grammar and vocabulary as well as on the practice of writing in various styles. Movies and video tapes are used as supplementary materials. Prerequisite: JAPN 0600 or equivalent.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hiroshi+Tajima">Hiroshi Tajima</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:00 - 14:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>07</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->
        
                <div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Korean</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>KREA 0100 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15235]</span></h3>


  	Begins with an introduction to the Korean writing system (Hangul) and focuses on building communicative competence in modern Korean in the four language modalities (listening, speaking, reading, writing). Provides a foundation for later work in spoken and written Korean. Six classroom hours per week. No prerequisite. Enrollment limited to 18. This is the first half of a year-long course whose first semester grade is normally a temporary one. Neither semester may be elected independently without special written permission. The final grade submitted at the end of the course work in KREA 0200 covers the entire year and is recorded as the final grade for both semesters.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>First Half of Year Course</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hyun+Ju+Ha">Hyun Ju Ha</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">09:00 - 09:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">09:00 - 09:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Korean</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>KREA 0100 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15236]</span></h3>


  	Begins with an introduction to the Korean writing system (Hangul) and focuses on building communicative competence in modern Korean in the four language modalities (listening, speaking, reading, writing). Provides a foundation for later work in spoken and written Korean. Six classroom hours per week. No prerequisite. Enrollment limited to 18. This is the first half of a year-long course whose first semester grade is normally a temporary one. Neither semester may be elected independently without special written permission. The final grade submitted at the end of the course work in KREA 0200 covers the entire year and is recorded as the final grade for both semesters.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>First Half of Year Course</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hyun+Ju+Ha">Hyun Ju Ha</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Intermediate Korean</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>KREA 0300 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15237]</span></h3>


  	An intermediate course in Korean designed to further communicative competence in spoken Korean and to provide additional reading practice in stylistically higher level materials that are progressively integrated into the given dialogues. Discussions on various aspects of Korean culture and society. Five classroom hours per week. Prerequisite: KREA 0200 or instructor permission.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hyun+Ju+Ha">Hyun Ju Ha</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">10:30 - 11:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">11:00 - 11:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>16</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Korean</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>KREA 0500 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15238]</span></h3>


  	Aims to help students develop an advanced level of communicative competence, with special focus on enhancing their reading comprehension, essay writing, and discourse (discussion  and presentation) skills.  Authentic reading materials from a variety of sources will be used to introduce various topics and issues pertaining to Korean society and culture, thus students' cultural understanding will also be enhanced.  Prerequisite:  KREA 0400 or equivalent or permission of instructor.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Cheol+Rin+Park">Cheol Rin Park</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">13:00 - 13:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>06</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Chinese: A History of the Language</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1510 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15239]</span></h3>


  	This course traces the historical evolution of modern Chinese, commonly known as Mandarin.  We will examine the uniqueness of Chinese characters, and explore their relationship to other features of the language, including word formation, phonology, grammar, and dialects.  The goal will be to understand the manner by which the written script has become so central to the development of Chinese civilization.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Zhuqing+Li">Zhuqing Li</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">15:00 - 17:30 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>15</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Translating Korean: Fiction, Poetry, Film and K-Pop</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1950W S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15240]</span></h3>


  	This course explores the theory and practice of translation in the context of Korean cultural production. Each week we shall grapple with a particular issue in translation studies in dialogue with a Korean-language text. By the end of this course students should be able to locate the tools necessary to carry out translations from Korean to English, to demonstrate an understanding of translation as a craft with its own standards, responsibilities, and complexities, and to have completed a significant translation project themselves. Advanced learners of the Korean language as well as native speakers of Korean are welcome. DPLL
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Diverse Perspectives in LL</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Samuel+E+Perry">Samuel E Perry</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 18:30 Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">China Modern: An Introduction to the Literature of Twentieth-Century China</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1070 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15242]</span></h3>


  	A general introduction to modern and contemporary Chinese literature from the May Fourth Movement to contemporary Taiwan and the People's Republic of China. Emphasizes reading of literary works in relation to topics such as cultural tradition, modernity, nationalism, revolution, class, gender, region, cultural commodification, and literary innovations. Readings in English. No previous knowledge of Chinese required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Lingzhen+Wang">Lingzhen Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Partridge Hall">Partridge Hall</a> 104</div>
						<div class="times">13:00 - 14:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Oct 5, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)">101 Thayer Street (VGQ 1st fl)</a> 116B</div>
						<div class="times">13:00 - 14:20 Tue, Thu - from Oct 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>10</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

	</div>

 </div>
</footer>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Modern Chinese Literature</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>CHIN 1040 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15243]</span></h3>


  	Introduces students to the most representative writers in 20th century China. Emphasizes textual and historical analyses. Major issues include Westernization, nationalism, revolution, class, gender, and literary innovations. Designated primarily as a literature course, rather than language class, and conducted entirely in Mandarin Chinese. Prerequisite: CHIN 0800. Instructor permission required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Lingzhen+Wang">Lingzhen Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Sayles Hall">Sayles Hall</a> 005</div>
						<div class="times">14:30 - 15:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Oct 5, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=111 Thayer St-Watson Institute">111 Thayer St-Watson Institute</a> 138</div>
						<div class="times">14:30 - 15:50 Tue, Thu - from Oct 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>03</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Media Korean</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>KREA 0910B S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15244]</span></h3>


  	Develop linguistic competence and deepen cultural understanding through exposure to a variety of media sources.  Built on the Content-based Instruction model and Genre-based Approach.  Discuss current Korean affairs and core issues of culture based on assigned materials. Develop reading and listening comprehension skills through pre-class activities, oral proficiency through in-class discussion and presentation, and writing proficiency through assigned essays writings, in addition to various integrative tasks.  Tuesday classes will focus on comprehending the text and source materials, Thursday classes will focus on related tasks and activities. Enrollment limited to 20. Conducted entirely in Korean.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hye-Sook+Wang">Hye-Sook Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">10:30 - 11:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>13</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

      <h4>Brown University</h4>
      <div class="content">
        <p><span class="city-state-country">Providence, Rhode Island 02912, USA</span><br />
          <span class="telephone">Phone: 401-863-1000</span><br />

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Modern Chinese I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>CHIN 0500 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15319]</span></h3>


  	An advanced course designed to enable students to read authentic materials. Students enhance their listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills; improve their narrative and descriptive abilities; and learn to express abstract ideas both orally and in writing. Five classroom meetings weekly. Prerequisite: CHIN 0250 or CHIN 0400 or permission of instructor.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Yang+Wang">Yang Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=J. Walter Wilson">J. Walter Wilson</a> 503</div>
						<div class="times">09:00 - 09:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=J. Walter Wilson">J. Walter Wilson</a> 503</div>
						<div class="times">09:00 - 10:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

	<div id="block-views-contact_information-block_1" class="clear-block block block-views ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Modern Chinese I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>CHIN 0500 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15320]</span></h3>


  	An advanced course designed to enable students to read authentic materials. Students enhance their listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills; improve their narrative and descriptive abilities; and learn to express abstract ideas both orally and in writing. Five classroom meetings weekly. Prerequisite: CHIN 0250 or CHIN 0400 or permission of instructor.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Yang+Wang">Yang Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=J. Walter Wilson">J. Walter Wilson</a> 503</div>
						<div class="times">10:30 - 11:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=J. Walter Wilson">J. Walter Wilson</a> 503</div>
						<div class="times">11:00 - 11:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Advanced Modern Chinese I</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>CHIN 0500 S03 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15321]</span></h3>


  	An advanced course designed to enable students to read authentic materials. Students enhance their listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills; improve their narrative and descriptive abilities; and learn to express abstract ideas both orally and in writing. Five classroom meetings weekly. Prerequisite: CHIN 0250 or CHIN 0400 or permission of instructor.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>18</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Yang+Wang">Yang Wang</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=J. Walter Wilson">J. Walter Wilson</a> 503</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=J. Walter Wilson">J. Walter Wilson</a> 503</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>04</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Elementary to Intermediate Chinese for Advanced Beginners</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>CHIN 0350 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15601]</span></h3>


  	This course is designed to enhance listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills for Chinese heritage students who have some prior knowledge of Chinese. Five classroom meetings weekly. Placement interview required.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Wenhui+Chen">Wenhui Chen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Sayles Hall">Sayles Hall</a> 306</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Sayles Hall">Sayles Hall</a> 306</div>
						<div class="times">12:00 - 12:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>12</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">
    <div class="banner-text">
      <a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/" title="" style="height:200px;" class="bare-banner-link"></a>    </div>
  </section>
      
  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Crafting Early Modern China: Handicraft, Witchcraft and Statecraft </h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1940A S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15617]</span></h3>


  	This course examines how Chinese cultural industry was shaped by socio-political institutions and religious practice between 1400 and 1900 CE. The course highlights the concept of craft, broadly understood as the ways of making artifacts and building social community by using environmental resources and through micro-political negotiations in everyday life. The course aims to equip students in ways to decipher the political, religious and gendered significance embedded in cultural products, including literature and decorative arts. We will explore artifacts from the following categories: literary illustration, painting and calligraphy, seals, ceramics, furniture, and textiles. Prerequisites: None.  DPLL
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>40</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Diverse Perspectives in LL</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Kaijun+Chen">Kaijun Chen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">15:00 - 17:30 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

<div class="wrapper">
<header id="header-region">
<section id="audience-gateways">
  <div class="marginator">
    <h6>Information For:</h6>
    <ul>
      <li id="gateway-current-students" class="first"><a href="/gateway/current-students">Current Students</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-faculty"><a href="/gateway/faculty">Faculty</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-staff"><a href="/gateway/staff">Staff</a></li>

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

  </section>
      
  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Literature and Social Inequality in Late Imperial China</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 0600 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 15655]</span></h3>


  	This course explores the social inequality and resistant movements represented in fiction, prose and poetry written in late imperial China. We will read literary works to investigate the inequalities sustained or challenged in five social arenas, namely socioeconomic class, gender, urban/rural division, ethnic distinction, and China/foreign difference. The balanced selection of readings in three major literary genres, written by male and female authors, cover topics including a social uprising, religious cult, legal trial, civil examination, courtesan culture, urban market, multiethnic court, diplomacy, and travel. Prerequisites: None.  DPLL
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Diverse Perspectives in LL</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Kaijun+Chen">Kaijun Chen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">18:40 - 20:00 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>05</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

  <div id="content">

                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Chinese Language in the Big Screen</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>CHIN 0920G S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16072]</span></h3>


  	This course is designed for advanced Chinese language students who have completed CHIN 0600 or equivalent.  You will gain language and culture proficiency through studying different genres of movies that reflect Chinese history, social issues and Chinese people’s values.  The primary objective of this course is to further develop your language proficiency in meaningful and entertaining contexts. By conducting research into the films, creating video summary, and sharing your work with your fellow students, you will build up your interpretive and presentational skills. In place of a final written exam, you will be asked to produce a mini-film.
					<h6>Section specific notes:</h6>
			<div class="section-text">This course will be meeting on Mondays 2-2:50P in Gerard House, room 204, the small library.</div>
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Lung-Hua+Hu">Lung-Hua Hu</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query="></a> </div>
						<div class="times">14:00 - 14:50 Mon - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Sciences Library">Sciences Library</a> 604</div>
						<div class="times">14:30 - 15:50 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>03</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Pop and Political: Modern Culture in Japan and the Koreas</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 0350 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16709]</span></h3>


  	This course introduces the modern cultures of Japan and Korea through an examination of events, artifacts, and cultural practices. With a broad understanding of culture as a general process of artistic and intellectual development, as a body of material artifacts, and as a social practice of ordinary life, we’ll focus our attention on the implications of studying culture in relation to popular media and political activism. Topics covered will include: colonial fiction, the re-creation of tradition, the proletarian arts, postwar children's culture, the globalization of popular music, myth in the DPRK, <i>shoji</i> print culture, and East Asian activism.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Samuel+E+Perry">Samuel E Perry</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">13:00 - 14:20 Tue, Thu - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>10</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Modern Korea: Politics, Culture, and Society</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 0530 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17082]</span></h3>


  	Korea has a long and rich history that often goes underappreciated in the U.S. and other parts of the world. At the same time, studying Korea provides a unique vantage point for understanding major processes in East Asia and the world, both in the past and the present. The aim of this introductory course is to use illuminating aspects of the Korean historical experience to set the path for an educational journey that encompasses not only learning about the Korean past, but also expanding our ability to approach cultural histories, as well as national cultures in general.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hieyoon+Kim">Hieyoon Kim</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">14:00 - 14:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>07</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Picturing Korea: History and Memory in South Korean Cinema</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1951C S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17083]</span></h3>


  	South Korean films have recently shown a thematic preoccupation with the nation’s tumultuous history by presenting diverse stories of past event and experience. They have also rendered different ways to address the issues related to important social developments and cultural phenomena. The aim of this seminar is to think about cinema’s role as a medium for visual storytelling and as a site for producing historical imaginations. Prior coursework on film and media and/or the history of East Asia is required, and students are expected to have a firm grounding in the methods of critical reading, textual analysis, and scholarly argumentation.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>20</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Hieyoon+Kim">Hieyoon Kim</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">16:00 - 18:30 Tue - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>09</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Introduction to Japanese Cinema</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1280 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17238]</span></h3>


  	This course examines the cinema of Japan, from the 1930s to the present. Students will learn to “read” film as a visual text through a study of the basics of film editing and shot composition and will gain an understanding of cinema as art form, commercial product, and ideological tool through selected articles on film theory and published analyses of the assigned films. In addition, we will place the films within their specific context through a study of Japanese history, religious thought, and cultural trends. DPLL
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>30</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Diverse Perspectives in LL</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Jennifer+Cullen">Jennifer Cullen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
									<dd>
						<span class="room"> </span>
						<span class="times">15:00 - 17:30 Wed - from Sep 6, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017</span>
						</dd>
							
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>17</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>

	<h5>Students &amp; Alumni</h5>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Reading and Writing of the Honors Thesis</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>EAST 1930 S19 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 17338]</span></h3>


  	Prior admission to honors candidacy required. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>First Half of Year Course</dd>
			
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Edward+S+Steinfeld">Edward S Steinfeld</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

        <section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/east-asian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.east-asian-studies/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">
    <div class="banner-text">
      <a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/" title="" style="height:200px;" class="bare-banner-link"></a>    </div>
  </section>
      
  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                              <div id="tabs-wrapper" class="clear-block">
            <ul class="tabs primary">
              <li ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/chin">CHIN</a></li>
<li class="active" ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/east" class="active">EAST</a></li>
<li ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/japn">JAPN</a></li>
<li ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/krea">KREA</a></li>

            </ul>
          </div>
                                        <div class="clear-block"> <div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="east">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="EAST0350">
					<h4>Pop and Political: Modern Culture in Japan and the Koreas</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course introduces the modern cultures of Japan and Korea through an examination of events, artifacts, and cultural practices. With a broad understanding of culture as a general process of artistic and intellectual development, as a body of material artifacts, and as a social practice of ordinary life, we’ll focus our attention on the implications of studying culture in relation to popular media and political activism. Topics covered will include: colonial fiction, the re-creation of tradition, the proletarian arts, postwar children's culture, the globalization of popular music, myth in the DPRK, <i>shoji</i> print culture, and East Asian activism. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=16709">EAST 0350 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Perry</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST0530">
					<h4>Modern Korea: Politics, Culture, and Society</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Korea has a long and rich history that often goes underappreciated in the U.S. and other parts of the world. At the same time, studying Korea provides a unique vantage point for understanding major processes in East Asia and the world, both in the past and the present. The aim of this introductory course is to use illuminating aspects of the Korean historical experience to set the path for an educational journey that encompasses not only learning about the Korean past, but also expanding our ability to approach cultural histories, as well as national cultures in general. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17082">EAST 0530 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Kim</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST0600">
					<h4>Literature and Social Inequality in Late Imperial China</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course explores the social inequality and resistant movements represented in fiction, prose and poetry written in late imperial China. We will read literary works to investigate the inequalities sustained or challenged in five social arenas, namely socioeconomic class, gender, urban/rural division, ethnic distinction, and China/foreign difference. The balanced selection of readings in three major literary genres, written by male and female authors, cover topics including a social uprising, religious cult, legal trial, civil examination, courtesan culture, urban market, multiethnic court, diplomacy, and travel. Prerequisites: None.  DPLL </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15655">EAST 0600 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Chen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1070">
					<h4>China Modern: An Introduction to the Literature of Twentieth-Century China</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A general introduction to modern and contemporary Chinese literature from the May Fourth Movement to contemporary Taiwan and the People's Republic of China. Emphasizes reading of literary works in relation to topics such as cultural tradition, modernity, nationalism, revolution, class, gender, region, cultural commodification, and literary innovations. Readings in English. No previous knowledge of Chinese required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15242">EAST 1070 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wang</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1280">
					<h4>Introduction to Japanese Cinema</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course examines the cinema of Japan, from the 1930s to the present. Students will learn to “read” film as a visual text through a study of the basics of film editing and shot composition and will gain an understanding of cinema as art form, commercial product, and ideological tool through selected articles on film theory and published analyses of the assigned films. In addition, we will place the films within their specific context through a study of Japanese history, religious thought, and cultural trends. DPLL </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17238">EAST 1280 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Cullen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1510">
					<h4>Chinese: A History of the Language</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course traces the historical evolution of modern Chinese, commonly known as Mandarin.  We will examine the uniqueness of Chinese characters, and explore their relationship to other features of the language, including word formation, phonology, grammar, and dialects.  The goal will be to understand the manner by which the written script has become so central to the development of Chinese civilization. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15239">EAST 1510 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Li</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1910">
					<h4>Independent Study</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Sections numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=12650">EAST 1910 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>

														<dl>

																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1940A">
					<h4>Crafting Early Modern China: Handicraft, Witchcraft and Statecraft </h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course examines how Chinese cultural industry was shaped by socio-political institutions and religious practice between 1400 and 1900 CE. The course highlights the concept of craft, broadly understood as the ways of making artifacts and building social community by using environmental resources and through micro-political negotiations in everyday life. The course aims to equip students in ways to decipher the political, religious and gendered significance embedded in cultural products, including literature and decorative arts. We will explore artifacts from the following categories: literary illustration, painting and calligraphy, seals, ceramics, furniture, and textiles. Prerequisites: None.  DPLL </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15617">EAST 1940A S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Chen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1950W">
					<h4>Translating Korean: Fiction, Poetry, Film and K-Pop</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course explores the theory and practice of translation in the context of Korean cultural production. Each week we shall grapple with a particular issue in translation studies in dialogue with a Korean-language text. By the end of this course students should be able to locate the tools necessary to carry out translations from Korean to English, to demonstrate an understanding of translation as a craft with its own standards, responsibilities, and complexities, and to have completed a significant translation project themselves. Advanced learners of the Korean language as well as native speakers of Korean are welcome. DPLL </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15240">EAST 1950W S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Perry</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="EAST1951C">
					<h4>Picturing Korea: History and Memory in South Korean Cinema</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">South Korean films have recently shown a thematic preoccupation with the nation’s tumultuous history by presenting diverse stories of past event and experience. They have also rendered different ways to address the issues related to important social developments and cultural phenomena. The aim of this seminar is to think about cinema’s role as a medium for visual storytelling and as a site for producing historical imaginations. Prior coursework on film and media and/or the history of East Asia is required, and students are expected to have a firm grounding in the methods of critical reading, textual analysis, and scholarly argumentation. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=17083">EAST 1951C S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Kim</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>

<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->
        
                <div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                              <div id="tabs-wrapper" class="clear-block">
            <ul class="tabs primary">
              <li ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/chin">CHIN</a></li>
<li ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/east">EAST</a></li>
<li class="active" ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/japn" class="active">JAPN</a></li>
<li ><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/krea">KREA</a></li>

            </ul>
          </div>
                                        <div class="clear-block"> <div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="japn">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="JAPN0100">
					<h4>Basic Japanese</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Introduction to Japanese language. Emphasizes the attainment of good spoken control of Japanese and develops a foundation of literacy. No prerequisites. This is the first half of a year-long course whose first semester grade is normally a temporary one. Neither semester may be elected independently without special written permission. The final grade submitted at the end of the course work in JAPN 0200 covers the entire year and is recorded as the final grade for both semesters. The East Asian Studies department wishes to provide language instruction to all interested students. If you are unable to register for this course due to enrollment limits but are dedicated to learning Japanese, please contact the instructor via email. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15227">JAPN 0100 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jackson</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15228">JAPN 0100 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jackson</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15229">JAPN 0100 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jackson</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="JAPN0300">
					<h4>Intermediate Japanese</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Further practice of patterns and structures of the language. Readings are introduced on aspects of Japanese culture and society to develop reading and writing skills, enhance vocabulary, and provide points of departure for conversation in Japanese. Prerequisite: JAPN 0200 or equivalent. The East Asian Studies department wishes to provide language instruction to all interested students. If you are unable to register for this course due to enrollment limits but are dedicated to learning Japanese, please contact the instructor via email. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15231">JAPN 0300 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Tajima</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15232">JAPN 0300 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Tajima</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="JAPN0500">
					<h4>Advanced Japanese I</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Continued practice in reading, writing, and speaking. Emphasizes the development of reading proficiency and speaking in cultural contexts. Students read actual articles and selections from Japanese newspapers. Course includes translation, with writing and discussion in Japanese. Films and video tapes are shown as supplementary materials. Prerequisite: JAPN 0400 or equivalent. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15233">JAPN 0500 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jackson</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="JAPN0700">
					<h4>Advanced Japanese II</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Reading of articles from Japan's press with discussion in Japanese. Focuses on explanations and drills on the fine points in grammar and vocabulary as well as on the practice of writing in various styles. Movies and video tapes are used as supplementary materials. Prerequisite: JAPN 0600 or equivalent. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=15234">JAPN 0700 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Tajima</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="JAPN1910">
					<h4>Independent Study</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Reading materials for research in Japanese. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=13458">JAPN 1910 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Jackson</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=13459">JAPN 1910 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>McClain</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/east-asian-studies/courses/detail?term=201710&crn=13460">JAPN 1910 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Tajima</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>

				</li>
					</ul>
		
	</div> <!-- end .course-section -->



</div>



<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
 </div>
